commits.message:
Process output capturing is symlink-aware (#17496)

Fixes #16854 

Change is minimal, wire `symlink_behavior` through the Rust code, setting it to `Oblivious` most places except process output collection. Then when we are collecting path stats and are told to be `Aware`, we return a `Symlink` stat.

Easy peasy.

Add `per_platform` object (#17334)

This object allows users (when the types allow) to specify a value of `per_platform(...)` mapping platform names to homogenous values. The platform value is looked up in the rule engine to allow for differing execution environments.

I'm also using it for asset's sources being `http_source`s.

(And I renamed `HTTPSource` to `http_source` so the user help has the object looking like the type)
Support parsing targets from additional paths not containing BUILD files. (#17451)

Fix memoization of `CoarsenedTarget.closure` (#17516)

Memoization of `CoarsenedTargets.closure()` relies on shared memoization across a walk in each `CoarsenedTarget`. That memoization was not working.

Fixes #17509.

Don't require hardcoded name in python_distribution.provides (#17522)

It might be provided by a SetupKwargs-generating plugin.

Also fix various example uses of the legacy "setup_py()" name
to "python_artifact()", which is the name we document.

Rescue Jar tool source code (#17514)

Rescue jar tool source code from Pants V1 and ship it as embedded resources

Skip loading of local cache data when possible (#17495)

Closes https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/issues/17448.

Persist digests before emitting them in `fs_util` (#17525)

Otherwise they will not have been written to the LMDB store (although they will have been uploaded to any configured remote stores via the `ensure_uploaded_to_remote`).

Fix line breaks in a docs page. (#17527)

Also tweak some phrasing, which currently implies that case
doesn't matter in env var names...

Fix leftover `todo!()` (#17523)

Fixes the TODO by making subsetting always oblivious
Update team pages for SJ and Dan! (#17534)

Adds workunit for interactive processes. (#17544)

While working on #16825, we discovered that parts of the trace for our `experimental_run_shell_command` were not captured. That's because there was no work unit preserved.

This adds such a work unit.

Do not try to create `""` output directory in `CreateArchive` (#17538) This fixes a bug/regression in 2.13 -> 2.14 where `CreateArchive` requires an output directory. In 2.13 this'd pass `""` as a create-directory request, and that'd... do something. In 2.14 the Rust code uses `DigestTries` to improve performance, but an empty trie component generates an error: ``` 15:00:12.12 [ERROR] 1 Exception encountered: Engine traceback: in select in pants.core.goals.package.package_asset in pants_backend_oci.goals.package.package_oci_image (examples:oci) in pants_backend_oci.util_rules.build_image_bundle.build_oci_bundle_package in pants.core.util_rules.archive.create_archive Traceback (no traceback): Exception: Path `` was unexpectedly empty ``` I believe this change in behavior comes from this optimization by @Eric-Arellano: https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/pull/16648/files#diff-78b61c9a9b42b3895a2c71b90e31aceee5a5f38780edddbd4daec17ee4386d98R475. I believe backporting this to the 2.14 series makes sense to fix the regression. If the output directory should be required, a proper breaking change might be in order for 2.15 with a renaming of the parameter (output_file**name** -> output_file**path**) and proper diagnostic.

Fix loading of `SymlinkNodes` from the `Store`. (#17549)

When loading `Directory` protos from the `Store`, we were not loading their `SymlinkNode`s, which caused a mismatching digest when loading `Snapshot`s which contain symlinks.

Fixes #17542.

Export metadata about a packaged docker image (#17299)

This has the docker target output a `$name.docker-info.json` file when packaged, to end up in `dist/` or for use as a dependency. The file contains the full specification of the packaged image, including each of the `registry/repository:tag` names it was tagged with. This stops users from having to parse the pants output (or query docker itself) if they need this information, such as to place into a cloud deploy template, or to run the image locally.

Fix deprecation message for `threading.Event` (#17552)

Closes https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/issues/17551#issuecomment-1315562857.
New dependency rules Plugin API (#17550)

Support newer pip versions. (#17555)

Plumbs --pip-version through to pex commands that support it.

Newer pips have perf improvements that may benefit users, in particular for very long-running resolves.

Does not change the default. We can do that via deprecation in a followup.
Add Whisper to Pants user list (#17560)

Generate help info about target_field_name to the docsite. (#17138)

Tweaks where this info is displayed in cli help, to match.

[ci skip-rust]
[ci skip-build-wheels]

Minor cleanups to fmt/lint (#17140)

`registration_rules` -> `rules`
`partitioner_type` is now a classvar (thanks Stu!)

[ci skip-rust]
[ci skip-build-wheels]

Tidy up environments documentation (#17144)

Adds documentation requested in #17095, and also renames the `_environment` field to `environment`.

Fix spurious linebreaks in the CI docs page. (#17154)

Unfortunately readme.com interprets soft breaks as hard breaks...

[ci skip-rust]

[ci skip-build-wheels]

Add OpenAPI linting with Spectral (#17137)

This PR adds linting support for `openapi_document()` using [Spectral](https://github.com/stoplightio/spectral), though the implementation currently only supports Spectral's own ruleset `spectral:oas`.

I do plan on adding support for a [custom ruleset](https://meta.stoplight.io/docs/spectral/e5b9616d6d50c-custom-rulesets) file in the near future, but since those files have nested `extends:` capabilities it seemed like a party to save for another day ([custom functions](https://meta.stoplight.io/docs/spectral/a781e290eb9f9-custom-functions) is future Jonas' problem as well).

[ci skip-rust]
[ci skip-build-wheels]
Prepare 2.13.1rc1 release notes. (#17160)
Prepare 2.15.0.dev4 release notes. (#17161)

Always include relevant params in workunit descriptions, and include descriptions in traces by default (#17119)

In order to:
1. begin to render an environment in more places (when one is in use)
2. add more human readable, useful context to errors when they occur

... this change appends all `EngineAwareParams` to the workunit descriptions of tasks, and renders workunit descriptions in engine backtraces by default.

----

The impact on common use is fairly subtle, because this does not impact `Process` (which represents the majority of labeled `debug` level workunits), but you can see it in test output rendering:
```
09:56:14.93 [INFO] Completed: Run Pytest - (environment:docker, src/python/pants/util/strutil_test.py:tests) - succeeded.
```

You can see the impact on backtraces in the changes to the tests. As one example (note: this is with `--no-print-stacktrace`):
```
$ ./pants --no-print-stacktrace dependencies src/python/pants/base/::
10:01:35.84 [ERROR] 1 Exception encountered:

Engine traceback:
  in `dependencies` goal
  in Resolve direct dependencies of target - src/python/pants/base/exception_sink_integration_test.py:exception_sink_integration_test

InvalidSpecPathError: Invalid address /testprojects:pants_plugins_directory from the `dependencies` field from the target src/python/pants/base/exception_sink_integration_test.py:exception_sink_integration_test. Cannot use absolute paths.
```

While this information is lightly redundant with the use cases which were improved in #14468, there are likely to be other errors which currently do not have enough context added. And almost no explicit inclusion of the environment in error messages currently happens, but would need to if context were to be added manually.

[ci skip-build-wheels]
Prepare 2.14.0rc3 release notes. (#17159)

go/cgo: use debug level to reduce work unit verbosity (#17164)

Set debug log level on processes used to compile and link cgo artifacts. This will prevent the work units for the individual steps from being rendered at INFO level. They should only be visible when actually in the swim lanes display.

Also, add import path to process descriptions.

[ci skip-rust]

go: enable cgo by default (#17086)

Enable `--golang-cgo-enabled` by default. The option has not been released yet so it is safe to change the default now.

[ci skip-rust]

[ci skip-build-wheels]

go/gofmt: filter out non-go files from file list (#17171)

Filter out non-Go files, e.g. assembly files or C files, from the list of files to be formatted.

[ci skip-rust]

[ci skip-build-wheels]

Remote execution is only enabled globally if environments aren't used at all (#17135)

It's now possible to use environments generally, but for the current env target to be set to None, thanks to https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/pull/16983.

This was resulting in faulty logic that we were treating the `--remote-execution` flag as a global switch for remoting, when really if environment targets are used at all, then we should only use remoting when a `remote_environment` target is active.

[ci skip-rust]
[ci skip-build-wheels]

Fix quoting of GitHub Actions expressions. (#17172)

We were previously using ${{ expr }} in f-strings, which
caused them to emit ${ expr } into the YAML, which is incorrect.

Correctly quoting this in an f-string would require 4 braces,
which is unwieldy. Plus, it's common while editing to turn a
regular string into an f-string or vice versa, and it would be
very easy to neglect to change the quoting as needed.

Instead, we introduce a helper function and use it exclusively.

Note that this bug caused us to generate useless, constant keys
for the GHA cache - in fact I noticed something was awry when
I saw CI builds re-building rust code after a successful cache
restore. Good thing our rust bootstrapping script is defensive.
I'd say we were pretty lucky if the only impact was performance;
This could potentially have lead us to actively step on our own
toes in bad ways.

Speed up print_engine_hash by not creating the venv. (#17168)

We only need the venv so that `python` can be called to emit
the full python version. But we don't need all the requirements
installed for that.

[ci skip-build-wheels]

Add basic support for pyright typechecking (#17163)

This PR adds the basic scaffolding for calling `pyright` via the `check` goal. It does not focus on any amount of optimization via partitions, nor does it include configuration - as I've never used `pyright` outside of VS Code, so I'm not the best person to do this.

(See #17141)

[ci skip-rust]
[ci skip-build-wheels]

Mask the environment name in `graph` and `specs_rules` (#17179)

As a first step toward #17129, this change "masks" the `EnvironmentName` for relevant APIs in `graph.py` and `specs_rules.py`, and pins them to the `__local__` environment.

The `@rule(.., _mask_types=[..])` argument triggers an assertion if the given type(s) are used in the identity of the `@rule` (i.e.: if the `@rule` "consumes" them from its scope). The impact of masking a type at an API boundary is an assertion that that type is not consumed by that API.

As described in #17129: we're pinning graph computations to the `__local__` environment for now, although we may eventually allow graph computations to execute in a configurable environment.

[ci skip-build-wheels]

Add Snowflake connector to module mapping (#17165)

Looks like there is no mapping for SF connector, this PR adds it.

SF repo: https://github.com/snowflakedb/snowflake-connector-python/tree/main/src/snowflake.

[ci skip-rust]
[ci skip-build-wheels]

Fix deprecation message for `env_vars` renames, and extend by a version. (#17187)

This deprecation is very cheap to keep.

[ci skip-rust]
[ci skip-build-wheels]

Begin migration to explicitly scoped environments (#17155)

As described in #17129: we would like `@goal_rule`s to eventually make their own decisions about which environments to use, generally by consuming targets to do so, but possibly also by pinning themselves to other environments via configuration.

This change builds on #17179, and introduces a migration from `Goal.environment_migrated = {False => True}`. All graph-introspection goals consume only the APIs which are pinned to the local environment by #17179, and so are trivially migrated here. Other goals trigger a deprecation warning like the following:
```
DEPRECATED: Not setting `Goal.environment_migrated=True` for `Goal` `generate-lockfiles` is scheduled to be removed in version 2.17.0.dev0.

See https://www.pantsbuild.org/v2.15/docs/plugin-upgrade-guide
```

Before calling #17129 done, we will migrate all internal goals to `Goal.environment_migrated=True`.

[ci skip-rust]
[ci skip-build-wheels]

pull_request.title: Support namespace-package that has some packages inside the repo and some outside
pull_request.body:
As discussed in https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/discussions/17286, I'm trying to support the use-case in which some of the packages of a namespace-package reside in the monorepo, while other are sourced elsewhere.

This draft change makes it so the ambiguity warning is not present anymore.
However:
1. I hope it is due to it being fixed and properly inferred, rather than the change only hiding the error.
2. I'm not sure how to replace `NAMESPACES` with an dynamic inference in `map_first_party_python_targets_to_modules` and `map_third_party_modules_to_addresses`.
3. I'm not sure about the naming of the new `enum`. Maybe change it to a `is_namespace_package` boolean or `ModuleProviderPackage` with `.NAMESPACE` and `.STANDARD`/`.REGULAR`?

issue.title: Warnings for un-inferred dependencies are not always consistant when using `pantsd`
issue.body:
**Bug description**
In [a reproduction example](https://github.com/TalAmuyal/pants-repro/tree/namespace_collision_example), I’m describing an issue I’m having.
For the issue to be reproduced consistently, I’m adding `--no-pantsd` to `pants package ::`.

**Pants version**
Tried with `2.14.0rc4` and `2.14.0rc5`.

**OS**
I encounter the bug on MacOS, didn't try on Linux.

**Additional info**
When discussing it on Slack, @benjyw clearified that what's happening is that since this is a warning (rather than an error) the result is still memoized in `pantsd`’s **memory**, so to reproduce it `pantsd` need to be avoided or restarted.
That’s **not** a persistent cache on disk, and thus it does not survives `pantsd` restarts and doesn't persist from one daemon-less run to another.

commits.message: Avoid the daemon rather than restarting Pants

issue.title: Support `BUILD`.`module_mapping` for Python package inference in `pants.toml`
issue.body:
It would be easier and more intuitive to support organization-internal (first-party) non-standard package names, if the [internal Pants mapping](https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/blob/0e6719ac88d20b500bf0294d2f810ccd2bcf8d7e/src/python/pants/backend/python/dependency_inference/default_module_mapping.py#L6) could be extended in the global configuration file (that is, the root `pants.toml`).

For example, given the following section in the root `pants.toml` file:
```toml
[python-infer]
module_mapping.add = {
  "company-python-utils" = ["db_utils", "string_utils"],
  "company-python-creds" = ["company_creds"],
}
```
The config parser will do an equivalent to the following (made up pseudo code):
```python
import itertools

from pants.backend.python.dependency_inference.default_module_mapping import DEFAULT_MODULE_MAPPING


def get_module_mapping(
    parsed_pants_toml: dict,
    parsed_build_file: dict,
) -> dict:
    """
    Apply `python-infer.module_mapping.add` and `BUILD.__defaults__.python_requirements.module_mapping` if configured.
    """
    additions = itertools.chain(
        parsed_pants_toml.get("python-infer", {}).get("module_mapping", {}).get("add", {}).items(),
        parsed_build_file.get("__defaults__", {}).get("python_requirements", {}).get("module_mapping", {}).items(),
    )

    result = DEFAULT_MODULE_MAPPING.copy()
    for pypi_name, import_names in additions:
        result[pypi_name] = tuple(import_names)

    return result
```

For a repository that has an extensive use of non-standard package names in multiple packages, this will be a simple, efficient, and elegant solution.

Assuming the team is onboard with this idea (or a variation of it), I'd like to offer to put up a PR with an implementation.
Note that in that case, that would be my first PR for Pants, so I'd appreciate a few pointers on how to adjust the example above (or the alternative) to the actual project.

        parsed_pants_toml.get("python-infer", {}).get("module_mapping", {}).get("add", {}).items(),
        parsed_build_file.get("__defaults__", {}).get("python_requirements", {}).get("module_mapping", {}).items(),
    )

    result = DEFAULT_MODULE_MAPPING.copy()
    for pypi_name, import_names in additions:
        result[pypi_name] = tuple(import_names)

    return result
```

For a repository that has an extensive use of non-standard package names in multiple packages, this will be a simple, efficient, and elegant solution.

Assuming the team is onboard with this idea (or a variation of it), I'd like to offer to put up a PR with an implementation.
Note that in that case, that would be my first PR for Pants, so I'd appreciate a few pointers on how to adjust the example above (or the alternative) to the actual project.

My bad, I will clarify
There are 2 use-cases I see for this feature.

The first use-case is an organization-internal package which is in another repo.
For example, if it is owned by another division in the company and thus has its own (maybe mono) repo.

The second use-case is that there is a package on PyPi that is not yet in the [internal Pants mapping](https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/blob/0e6719ac88d20b500bf0294d2f810ccd2bcf8d7e/src/python/pants/backend/python/dependency_inference/default_module_mapping.py#L6), so as a temp fix it can be added for that repo.

commits.message:
Process output capturing is symlink-aware (#17496)

Fixes #16854 

Change is minimal, wire `symlink_behavior` through the Rust code, setting it to `Oblivious` most places except process output collection. Then when we are collecting path stats and are told to be `Aware`, we return a `Symlink` stat.

Easy peasy.

Add `per_platform` object (#17334)

This object allows users (when the types allow) to specify a value of `per_platform(...)` mapping platform names to homogenous values. The platform value is looked up in the rule engine to allow for differing execution environments.

I'm also using it for asset's sources being `http_source`s.

(And I renamed `HTTPSource` to `http_source` so the user help has the object looking like the type)
Support parsing targets from additional paths not containing BUILD files. (#17451)

Fix memoization of `CoarsenedTarget.closure` (#17516)

Memoization of `CoarsenedTargets.closure()` relies on shared memoization across a walk in each `CoarsenedTarget`. That memoization was not working.

Fixes #17509.

Don't require hardcoded name in python_distribution.provides (#17522)

It might be provided by a SetupKwargs-generating plugin.

Also fix various example uses of the legacy "setup_py()" name
to "python_artifact()", which is the name we document.

Rescue Jar tool source code (#17514)

Rescue jar tool source code from Pants V1 and ship it as embedded resources

Skip loading of local cache data when possible (#17495)

Closes https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/issues/17448.

Persist digests before emitting them in `fs_util` (#17525)

Otherwise they will not have been written to the LMDB store (although they will have been uploaded to any configured remote stores via the `ensure_uploaded_to_remote`).

Fix line breaks in a docs page. (#17527)

Also tweak some phrasing, which currently implies that case
doesn't matter in env var names...

Fix leftover `todo!()` (#17523)

Fixes the TODO by making subsetting always oblivious
Update team pages for SJ and Dan! (#17534)

Adds workunit for interactive processes. (#17544)

While working on #16825, we discovered that parts of the trace for our `experimental_run_shell_command` were not captured. That's because there was no work unit preserved.

This adds such a work unit.

Do not try to create `""` output directory in `CreateArchive` (#17538) This fixes a bug/regression in 2.13 -> 2.14 where `CreateArchive` requires an output directory. In 2.13 this'd pass `""` as a create-directory request, and that'd... do something. In 2.14 the Rust code uses `DigestTries` to improve performance, but an empty trie component generates an error: ``` 15:00:12.12 [ERROR] 1 Exception encountered: Engine traceback: in select in pants.core.goals.package.package_asset in pants_backend_oci.goals.package.package_oci_image (examples:oci) in pants_backend_oci.util_rules.build_image_bundle.build_oci_bundle_package in pants.core.util_rules.archive.create_archive Traceback (no traceback): Exception: Path `` was unexpectedly empty ``` I believe this change in behavior comes from this optimization by @Eric-Arellano: https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/pull/16648/files#diff-78b61c9a9b42b3895a2c71b90e31aceee5a5f38780edddbd4daec17ee4386d98R475. I believe backporting this to the 2.14 series makes sense to fix the regression. If the output directory should be required, a proper breaking change might be in order for 2.15 with a renaming of the parameter (output_file**name** -> output_file**path**) and proper diagnostic.

Fix loading of `SymlinkNodes` from the `Store`. (#17549)

When loading `Directory` protos from the `Store`, we were not loading their `SymlinkNode`s, which caused a mismatching digest when loading `Snapshot`s which contain symlinks.

Fixes #17542.

Export metadata about a packaged docker image (#17299)

This has the docker target output a `$name.docker-info.json` file when packaged, to end up in `dist/` or for use as a dependency. The file contains the full specification of the packaged image, including each of the `registry/repository:tag` names it was tagged with. This stops users from having to parse the pants output (or query docker itself) if they need this information, such as to place into a cloud deploy template, or to run the image locally.

Fix deprecation message for `threading.Event` (#17552)

Closes https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/issues/17551#issuecomment-1315562857.
New dependency rules Plugin API (#17550)

Support newer pip versions. (#17555)

Plumbs --pip-version through to pex commands that support it.

Newer pips have perf improvements that may benefit users, in particular for very long-running resolves.

Does not change the default. We can do that via deprecation in a followup.
Add Whisper to Pants user list (#17560)

Generate help info about target_field_name to the docsite. (#17138)

Tweaks where this info is displayed in cli help, to match.

[ci skip-rust]
[ci skip-build-wheels]

Minor cleanups to fmt/lint (#17140)

`registration_rules` -> `rules`
`partitioner_type` is now a classvar (thanks Stu!)

[ci skip-rust]
[ci skip-build-wheels]

Tidy up environments documentation (#17144)

Adds documentation requested in #17095, and also renames the `_environment` field to `environment`.

Fix spurious linebreaks in the CI docs page. (#17154)

Unfortunately readme.com interprets soft breaks as hard breaks...

[ci skip-rust]

[ci skip-build-wheels]

Add OpenAPI linting with Spectral (#17137)

This PR adds linting support for `openapi_document()` using [Spectral](https://github.com/stoplightio/spectral), though the implementation currently only supports Spectral's own ruleset `spectral:oas`.

I do plan on adding support for a [custom ruleset](https://meta.stoplight.io/docs/spectral/e5b9616d6d50c-custom-rulesets) file in the near future, but since those files have nested `extends:` capabilities it seemed like a party to save for another day ([custom functions](https://meta.stoplight.io/docs/spectral/a781e290eb9f9-custom-functions) is future Jonas' problem as well).

[ci skip-rust]
[ci skip-build-wheels]
Prepare 2.13.1rc1 release notes. (#17160)
Prepare 2.15.0.dev4 release notes. (#17161)

Always include relevant params in workunit descriptions, and include descriptions in traces by default (#17119)

In order to:
1. begin to render an environment in more places (when one is in use)
2. add more human readable, useful context to errors when they occur

... this change appends all `EngineAwareParams` to the workunit descriptions of tasks, and renders workunit descriptions in engine backtraces by default.

----

The impact on common use is fairly subtle, because this does not impact `Process` (which represents the majority of labeled `debug` level workunits), but you can see it in test output rendering:
```
09:56:14.93 [INFO] Completed: Run Pytest - (environment:docker, src/python/pants/util/strutil_test.py:tests) - succeeded.
```

You can see the impact on backtraces in the changes to the tests. As one example (note: this is with `--no-print-stacktrace`):
```
$ ./pants --no-print-stacktrace dependencies src/python/pants/base/::
10:01:35.84 [ERROR] 1 Exception encountered:

Engine traceback:
  in `dependencies` goal
  in Resolve direct dependencies of target - src/python/pants/base/exception_sink_integration_test.py:exception_sink_integration_test

InvalidSpecPathError: Invalid address /testprojects:pants_plugins_directory from the `dependencies` field from the target src/python/pants/base/exception_sink_integration_test.py:exception_sink_integration_test. Cannot use absolute paths.
```

While this information is lightly redundant with the use cases which were improved in #14468, there are likely to be other errors which currently do not have enough context added. And almost no explicit inclusion of the environment in error messages currently happens, but would need to if context were to be added manually.

[ci skip-build-wheels]
Prepare 2.14.0rc3 release notes. (#17159)

go/cgo: use debug level to reduce work unit verbosity (#17164)

Set debug log level on processes used to compile and link cgo artifacts. This will prevent the work units for the individual steps from being rendered at INFO level. They should only be visible when actually in the swim lanes display.

Also, add import path to process descriptions.

[ci skip-rust]

go: enable cgo by default (#17086)

Enable `--golang-cgo-enabled` by default. The option has not been released yet so it is safe to change the default now.

[ci skip-rust]

[ci skip-build-wheels]

go/gofmt: filter out non-go files from file list (#17171)

Filter out non-Go files, e.g. assembly files or C files, from the list of files to be formatted.

[ci skip-rust]

[ci skip-build-wheels]

Remote execution is only enabled globally if environments aren't used at all (#17135)

It's now possible to use environments generally, but for the current env target to be set to None, thanks to https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/pull/16983.

This was resulting in faulty logic that we were treating the `--remote-execution` flag as a global switch for remoting, when really if environment targets are used at all, then we should only use remoting when a `remote_environment` target is active.

[ci skip-rust]
[ci skip-build-wheels]

Fix quoting of GitHub Actions expressions. (#17172)

We were previously using ${{ expr }} in f-strings, which
caused them to emit ${ expr } into the YAML, which is incorrect.

Correctly quoting this in an f-string would require 4 braces,
which is unwieldy. Plus, it's common while editing to turn a
regular string into an f-string or vice versa, and it would be
very easy to neglect to change the quoting as needed.

Instead, we introduce a helper function and use it exclusively.

Note that this bug caused us to generate useless, constant keys
for the GHA cache - in fact I noticed something was awry when
I saw CI builds re-building rust code after a successful cache
restore. Good thing our rust bootstrapping script is defensive.
I'd say we were pretty lucky if the only impact was performance;
This could potentially have lead us to actively step on our own
toes in bad ways.

Speed up print_engine_hash by not creating the venv. (#17168)

We only need the venv so that `python` can be called to emit
the full python version. But we don't need all the requirements
installed for that.

[ci skip-build-wheels]

Add basic support for pyright typechecking (#17163)

This PR adds the basic scaffolding for calling `pyright` via the `check` goal. It does not focus on any amount of optimization via partitions, nor does it include configuration - as I've never used `pyright` outside of VS Code, so I'm not the best person to do this.

(See #17141)

[ci skip-rust]
[ci skip-build-wheels]

Mask the environment name in `graph` and `specs_rules` (#17179)

As a first step toward #17129, this change "masks" the `EnvironmentName` for relevant APIs in `graph.py` and `specs_rules.py`, and pins them to the `__local__` environment.

The `@rule(.., _mask_types=[..])` argument triggers an assertion if the given type(s) are used in the identity of the `@rule` (i.e.: if the `@rule` "consumes" them from its scope). The impact of masking a type at an API boundary is an assertion that that type is not consumed by that API.

As described in #17129: we're pinning graph computations to the `__local__` environment for now, although we may eventually allow graph computations to execute in a configurable environment.

[ci skip-build-wheels]

Add Snowflake connector to module mapping (#17165)

Looks like there is no mapping for SF connector, this PR adds it.

SF repo: https://github.com/snowflakedb/snowflake-connector-python/tree/main/src/snowflake.

[ci skip-rust]
[ci skip-build-wheels]

Fix deprecation message for `env_vars` renames, and extend by a version. (#17187)

This deprecation is very cheap to keep.

[ci skip-rust]
[ci skip-build-wheels]

Begin migration to explicitly scoped environments (#17155)

As described in #17129: we would like `@goal_rule`s to eventually make their own decisions about which environments to use, generally by consuming targets to do so, but possibly also by pinning themselves to other environments via configuration.

This change builds on #17179, and introduces a migration from `Goal.environment_migrated = {False => True}`. All graph-introspection goals consume only the APIs which are pinned to the local environment by #17179, and so are trivially migrated here. Other goals trigger a deprecation warning like the following:
```
DEPRECATED: Not setting `Goal.environment_migrated=True` for `Goal` `generate-lockfiles` is scheduled to be removed in version 2.17.0.dev0.

See https://www.pantsbuild.org/v2.15/docs/plugin-upgrade-guide
```

Before calling #17129 done, we will migrate all internal goals to `Goal.environment_migrated=True`.

[ci skip-rust]
[ci skip-build-wheels]

pull_request.title: Support namespace-package that has some packages inside the repo and some outside
pull_request.body:
As discussed in https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/discussions/17286, I'm trying to support the use-case in which some of the packages of a namespace-package reside in the monorepo, while other are sourced elsewhere.

This draft change makes it so the ambiguity warning is not present anymore.
However:
1. I hope it is due to it being fixed and properly inferred, rather than the change only hiding the error.
2. I'm not sure how to replace `NAMESPACES` with an dynamic inference in `map_first_party_python_targets_to_modules` and `map_third_party_modules_to_addresses`.
3. I'm not sure about the naming of the new `enum`. Maybe change it to a `is_namespace_package` boolean or `ModuleProviderPackage` with `.NAMESPACE` and `.STANDARD`/`.REGULAR`?

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -84,6 +98,28 @@ def find_all_python_projects(all_targets: AllTargets) -> AllPythonTargets:
     return AllPythonTargets(tuple(first_party), tuple(third_party))
 
 
+# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
+# Namespace packages collection
+# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
+
+
+class PythonNamespacePackages(frozenset):
+    """A set of Python namespace packages."""
+
+
+@rule(desc="Creating a collection of namespace-packages", level=LogLevel.DEBUG)
+async def collect_namespace_packages(
+    all_python_targets: AllPythonTargets,
+    python_setup: PythonSetup,
+) -> PythonNamespacePackages:
+    return PythonNamespacePackages(
+        module.split(".")[0]
+        for tgt in chain(all_python_targets.first_party, all_python_targets.third_party)
+        for module in (tgt.get(PythonRequirementModulesField).value or [])
+        if "." in module
comment.body:

I've started with making the `PotentialModuleProvider` and then removed it as I noticed `request.module` is available in `map_module_to_address`, where I assume we should have used the `.ancestry` field in the first place.
Also, I'm not sure that `calc_ancestry` has the logic you intended, but it does work both for the repro and our internal repo.

Please LMK what you think.

pull_request.title: Support namespace-package that has some packages inside the repo and some outside
pull_request.body:
As discussed in https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/discussions/17286, I'm trying to support the use-case in which some of the packages of a namespace-package reside in the monorepo, while other are sourced elsewhere.

This draft change makes it so the ambiguity warning is not present anymore.
However:
1. I hope it is due to it being fixed and properly inferred, rather than the change only hiding the error.
2. I'm not sure how to replace `NAMESPACES` with an dynamic inference in `map_first_party_python_targets_to_modules` and `map_third_party_modules_to_addresses`.
3. I'm not sure about the naming of the new `enum`. Maybe change it to a `is_namespace_package` boolean or `ModuleProviderPackage` with `.NAMESPACE` and `.STANDARD`/`.REGULAR`?

issue.title: Warnings for un-inferred dependencies are not always consistant when using `pantsd`
issue.body:
**Bug description**
In [a reproduction example](https://github.com/TalAmuyal/pants-repro/tree/namespace_collision_example), I’m describing an issue I’m having.
For the issue to be reproduced consistently, I’m adding `--no-pantsd` to `pants package ::`.

**Pants version**
Tried with `2.14.0rc4` and `2.14.0rc5`.

**OS**
I encounter the bug on MacOS, didn't try on Linux.

**Additional info**
When discussing it on Slack, @benjyw clearified that what's happening is that since this is a warning (rather than an error) the result is still memoized in `pantsd`’s **memory**, so to reproduce it `pantsd` need to be avoided or restarted.
That’s **not** a persistent cache on disk, and thus it does not survives `pantsd` restarts and doesn't persist from one daemon-less run to another.

commits.message: Avoid the daemon rather than restarting Pants

issue.title: Support `BUILD`.`module_mapping` for Python package inference in `pants.toml`
issue.body:
It would be easier and more intuitive to support organization-internal (first-party) non-standard package names, if the [internal Pants mapping](https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/blob/0e6719ac88d20b500bf0294d2f810ccd2bcf8d7e/src/python/pants/backend/python/dependency_inference/default_module_mapping.py#L6) could be extended in the global configuration file (that is, the root `pants.toml`).

For example, given the following section in the root `pants.toml` file:
```toml
[python-infer]
module_mapping.add = {
  "company-python-utils" = ["db_utils", "string_utils"],
  "company-python-creds" = ["company_creds"],
}
```
The config parser will do an equivalent to the following (made up pseudo code):
```python
import itertools

from pants.backend.python.dependency_inference.default_module_mapping import DEFAULT_MODULE_MAPPING


def get_module_mapping(
    parsed_pants_toml: dict,
    parsed_build_file: dict,
) -> dict:
    """
    Apply `python-infer.module_mapping.add` and `BUILD.__defaults__.python_requirements.module_mapping` if configured.
    """
    additions = itertools.chain(
        parsed_pants_toml.get("python-infer", {}).get("module_mapping", {}).get("add", {}).items(),
        parsed_build_file.get("__defaults__", {}).get("python_requirements", {}).get("module_mapping", {}).items(),
    )

    result = DEFAULT_MODULE_MAPPING.copy()
    for pypi_name, import_names in additions:
        result[pypi_name] = tuple(import_names)

    return result
```

For a repository that has an extensive use of non-standard package names in multiple packages, this will be a simple, efficient, and elegant solution.

Assuming the team is onboard with this idea (or a variation of it), I'd like to offer to put up a PR with an implementation.
Note that in that case, that would be my first PR for Pants, so I'd appreciate a few pointers on how to adjust the example above (or the alternative) to the actual project.

My bad, I will clarify
There are 2 use-cases I see for this feature.

The first use-case is an organization-internal package which is in another repo.
For example, if it is owned by another division in the company and thus has its own (maybe mono) repo.

The second use-case is that there is a package on PyPi that is not yet in the [internal Pants mapping](https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/blob/0e6719ac88d20b500bf0294d2f810ccd2bcf8d7e/src/python/pants/backend/python/dependency_inference/default_module_mapping.py#L6), so as a temp fix it can be added for that repo.

commits.message:
Process output capturing is symlink-aware (#17496)

Fixes #16854 

Change is minimal, wire `symlink_behavior` through the Rust code, setting it to `Oblivious` most places except process output collection. Then when we are collecting path stats and are told to be `Aware`, we return a `Symlink` stat.

Easy peasy.

Add `per_platform` object (#17334)

This object allows users (when the types allow) to specify a value of `per_platform(...)` mapping platform names to homogenous values. The platform value is looked up in the rule engine to allow for differing execution environments.

I'm also using it for asset's sources being `http_source`s.

(And I renamed `HTTPSource` to `http_source` so the user help has the object looking like the type)
Support parsing targets from additional paths not containing BUILD files. (#17451)

Fix memoization of `CoarsenedTarget.closure` (#17516)

Memoization of `CoarsenedTargets.closure()` relies on shared memoization across a walk in each `CoarsenedTarget`. That memoization was not working.

Fixes #17509.

Don't require hardcoded name in python_distribution.provides (#17522)

It might be provided by a SetupKwargs-generating plugin.

Also fix various example uses of the legacy "setup_py()" name
to "python_artifact()", which is the name we document.

Rescue Jar tool source code (#17514)

Rescue jar tool source code from Pants V1 and ship it as embedded resources

Skip loading of local cache data when possible (#17495)

Closes https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/issues/17448.

Persist digests before emitting them in `fs_util` (#17525)

Otherwise they will not have been written to the LMDB store (although they will have been uploaded to any configured remote stores via the `ensure_uploaded_to_remote`).

Fix line breaks in a docs page. (#17527)

Also tweak some phrasing, which currently implies that case
doesn't matter in env var names...

Fix leftover `todo!()` (#17523)

Fixes the TODO by making subsetting always oblivious
Update team pages for SJ and Dan! (#17534)

Adds workunit for interactive processes. (#17544)

While working on #16825, we discovered that parts of the trace for our `experimental_run_shell_command` were not captured. That's because there was no work unit preserved.

This adds such a work unit.

Do not try to create `""` output directory in `CreateArchive` (#17538) This fixes a bug/regression in 2.13 -> 2.14 where `CreateArchive` requires an output directory. In 2.13 this'd pass `""` as a create-directory request, and that'd... do something. In 2.14 the Rust code uses `DigestTries` to improve performance, but an empty trie component generates an error: ``` 15:00:12.12 [ERROR] 1 Exception encountered: Engine traceback: in select in pants.core.goals.package.package_asset in pants_backend_oci.goals.package.package_oci_image (examples:oci) in pants_backend_oci.util_rules.build_image_bundle.build_oci_bundle_package in pants.core.util_rules.archive.create_archive Traceback (no traceback): Exception: Path `` was unexpectedly empty ``` I believe this change in behavior comes from this optimization by @Eric-Arellano: https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/pull/16648/files#diff-78b61c9a9b42b3895a2c71b90e31aceee5a5f38780edddbd4daec17ee4386d98R475. I believe backporting this to the 2.14 series makes sense to fix the regression. If the output directory should be required, a proper breaking change might be in order for 2.15 with a renaming of the parameter (output_file**name** -> output_file**path**) and proper diagnostic.

Fix loading of `SymlinkNodes` from the `Store`. (#17549)

When loading `Directory` protos from the `Store`, we were not loading their `SymlinkNode`s, which caused a mismatching digest when loading `Snapshot`s which contain symlinks.

Fixes #17542.

Export metadata about a packaged docker image (#17299)

This has the docker target output a `$name.docker-info.json` file when packaged, to end up in `dist/` or for use as a dependency. The file contains the full specification of the packaged image, including each of the `registry/repository:tag` names it was tagged with. This stops users from having to parse the pants output (or query docker itself) if they need this information, such as to place into a cloud deploy template, or to run the image locally.

Fix deprecation message for `threading.Event` (#17552)

Closes https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/issues/17551#issuecomment-1315562857.
New dependency rules Plugin API (#17550)

Support newer pip versions. (#17555)

Plumbs --pip-version through to pex commands that support it.

Newer pips have perf improvements that may benefit users, in particular for very long-running resolves.

Does not change the default. We can do that via deprecation in a followup.
Add Whisper to Pants user list (#17560)

Generate help info about target_field_name to the docsite. (#17138)

Tweaks where this info is displayed in cli help, to match.

[ci skip-rust]
[ci skip-build-wheels]

Minor cleanups to fmt/lint (#17140)

`registration_rules` -> `rules`
`partitioner_type` is now a classvar (thanks Stu!)

[ci skip-rust]
[ci skip-build-wheels]

Tidy up environments documentation (#17144)

Adds documentation requested in #17095, and also renames the `_environment` field to `environment`.

Fix spurious linebreaks in the CI docs page. (#17154)

Unfortunately readme.com interprets soft breaks as hard breaks...

[ci skip-rust]

[ci skip-build-wheels]

Add OpenAPI linting with Spectral (#17137)

This PR adds linting support for `openapi_document()` using [Spectral](https://github.com/stoplightio/spectral), though the implementation currently only supports Spectral's own ruleset `spectral:oas`.

I do plan on adding support for a [custom ruleset](https://meta.stoplight.io/docs/spectral/e5b9616d6d50c-custom-rulesets) file in the near future, but since those files have nested `extends:` capabilities it seemed like a party to save for another day ([custom functions](https://meta.stoplight.io/docs/spectral/a781e290eb9f9-custom-functions) is future Jonas' problem as well).

[ci skip-rust]
[ci skip-build-wheels]
Prepare 2.13.1rc1 release notes. (#17160)
Prepare 2.15.0.dev4 release notes. (#17161)

Always include relevant params in workunit descriptions, and include descriptions in traces by default (#17119)

In order to:
1. begin to render an environment in more places (when one is in use)
2. add more human readable, useful context to errors when they occur

... this change appends all `EngineAwareParams` to the workunit descriptions of tasks, and renders workunit descriptions in engine backtraces by default.

----

The impact on common use is fairly subtle, because this does not impact `Process` (which represents the majority of labeled `debug` level workunits), but you can see it in test output rendering:
```
09:56:14.93 [INFO] Completed: Run Pytest - (environment:docker, src/python/pants/util/strutil_test.py:tests) - succeeded.
```

You can see the impact on backtraces in the changes to the tests. As one example (note: this is with `--no-print-stacktrace`):
```
$ ./pants --no-print-stacktrace dependencies src/python/pants/base/::
10:01:35.84 [ERROR] 1 Exception encountered:

Engine traceback:
  in `dependencies` goal
  in Resolve direct dependencies of target - src/python/pants/base/exception_sink_integration_test.py:exception_sink_integration_test

InvalidSpecPathError: Invalid address /testprojects:pants_plugins_directory from the `dependencies` field from the target src/python/pants/base/exception_sink_integration_test.py:exception_sink_integration_test. Cannot use absolute paths.
```

While this information is lightly redundant with the use cases which were improved in #14468, there are likely to be other errors which currently do not have enough context added. And almost no explicit inclusion of the environment in error messages currently happens, but would need to if context were to be added manually.

[ci skip-build-wheels]
Prepare 2.14.0rc3 release notes. (#17159)

go/cgo: use debug level to reduce work unit verbosity (#17164)

Set debug log level on processes used to compile and link cgo artifacts. This will prevent the work units for the individual steps from being rendered at INFO level. They should only be visible when actually in the swim lanes display.

Also, add import path to process descriptions.

[ci skip-rust]

go: enable cgo by default (#17086)

Enable `--golang-cgo-enabled` by default. The option has not been released yet so it is safe to change the default now.

[ci skip-rust]

[ci skip-build-wheels]

go/gofmt: filter out non-go files from file list (#17171)

Filter out non-Go files, e.g. assembly files or C files, from the list of files to be formatted.

[ci skip-rust]

[ci skip-build-wheels]

Remote execution is only enabled globally if environments aren't used at all (#17135)

It's now possible to use environments generally, but for the current env target to be set to None, thanks to https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/pull/16983.

This was resulting in faulty logic that we were treating the `--remote-execution` flag as a global switch for remoting, when really if environment targets are used at all, then we should only use remoting when a `remote_environment` target is active.

[ci skip-rust]
[ci skip-build-wheels]

Fix quoting of GitHub Actions expressions. (#17172)

We were previously using ${{ expr }} in f-strings, which
caused them to emit ${ expr } into the YAML, which is incorrect.

Correctly quoting this in an f-string would require 4 braces,
which is unwieldy. Plus, it's common while editing to turn a
regular string into an f-string or vice versa, and it would be
very easy to neglect to change the quoting as needed.

Instead, we introduce a helper function and use it exclusively.

Note that this bug caused us to generate useless, constant keys
for the GHA cache - in fact I noticed something was awry when
I saw CI builds re-building rust code after a successful cache
restore. Good thing our rust bootstrapping script is defensive.
I'd say we were pretty lucky if the only impact was performance;
This could potentially have lead us to actively step on our own
toes in bad ways.

Speed up print_engine_hash by not creating the venv. (#17168)

We only need the venv so that `python` can be called to emit
the full python version. But we don't need all the requirements
installed for that.

[ci skip-build-wheels]

Add basic support for pyright typechecking (#17163)

This PR adds the basic scaffolding for calling `pyright` via the `check` goal. It does not focus on any amount of optimization via partitions, nor does it include configuration - as I've never used `pyright` outside of VS Code, so I'm not the best person to do this.

(See #17141)

[ci skip-rust]
[ci skip-build-wheels]

Mask the environment name in `graph` and `specs_rules` (#17179)

As a first step toward #17129, this change "masks" the `EnvironmentName` for relevant APIs in `graph.py` and `specs_rules.py`, and pins them to the `__local__` environment.

The `@rule(.., _mask_types=[..])` argument triggers an assertion if the given type(s) are used in the identity of the `@rule` (i.e.: if the `@rule` "consumes" them from its scope). The impact of masking a type at an API boundary is an assertion that that type is not consumed by that API.

As described in #17129: we're pinning graph computations to the `__local__` environment for now, although we may eventually allow graph computations to execute in a configurable environment.

[ci skip-build-wheels]

Add Snowflake connector to module mapping (#17165)

Looks like there is no mapping for SF connector, this PR adds it.

SF repo: https://github.com/snowflakedb/snowflake-connector-python/tree/main/src/snowflake.

[ci skip-rust]
[ci skip-build-wheels]

Fix deprecation message for `env_vars` renames, and extend by a version. (#17187)

This deprecation is very cheap to keep.

[ci skip-rust]
[ci skip-build-wheels]

Begin migration to explicitly scoped environments (#17155)

As described in #17129: we would like `@goal_rule`s to eventually make their own decisions about which environments to use, generally by consuming targets to do so, but possibly also by pinning themselves to other environments via configuration.

This change builds on #17179, and introduces a migration from `Goal.environment_migrated = {False => True}`. All graph-introspection goals consume only the APIs which are pinned to the local environment by #17179, and so are trivially migrated here. Other goals trigger a deprecation warning like the following:
```
DEPRECATED: Not setting `Goal.environment_migrated=True` for `Goal` `generate-lockfiles` is scheduled to be removed in version 2.17.0.dev0.

See https://www.pantsbuild.org/v2.15/docs/plugin-upgrade-guide
```

Before calling #17129 done, we will migrate all internal goals to `Goal.environment_migrated=True`.

[ci skip-rust]
[ci skip-build-wheels]

pull_request.title: Support namespace-package that has some packages inside the repo and some outside
pull_request.body:
As discussed in https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/discussions/17286, I'm trying to support the use-case in which some of the packages of a namespace-package reside in the monorepo, while other are sourced elsewhere.

This draft change makes it so the ambiguity warning is not present anymore.
However:
1. I hope it is due to it being fixed and properly inferred, rather than the change only hiding the error.
2. I'm not sure how to replace `NAMESPACES` with an dynamic inference in `map_first_party_python_targets_to_modules` and `map_third_party_modules_to_addresses`.
3. I'm not sure about the naming of the new `enum`. Maybe change it to a `is_namespace_package` boolean or `ModuleProviderPackage` with `.NAMESPACE` and `.STANDARD`/`.REGULAR`?

issue.title: Warnings for un-inferred dependencies are not always consistant when using `pantsd`
issue.body:
**Bug description**
In [a reproduction example](https://github.com/TalAmuyal/pants-repro/tree/namespace_collision_example), I’m describing an issue I’m having.
For the issue to be reproduced consistently, I’m adding `--no-pantsd` to `pants package ::`.

**Pants version**
Tried with `2.14.0rc4` and `2.14.0rc5`.

**OS**
I encounter the bug on MacOS, didn't try on Linux.

**Additional info**
When discussing it on Slack, @benjyw clearified that what's happening is that since this is a warning (rather than an error) the result is still memoized in `pantsd`’s **memory**, so to reproduce it `pantsd` need to be avoided or restarted.
That’s **not** a persistent cache on disk, and thus it does not survives `pantsd` restarts and doesn't persist from one daemon-less run to another.

issue.title: Support `BUILD`.`module_mapping` for Python package inference in `pants.toml`
issue.body:
It would be easier and more intuitive to support organization-internal (first-party) non-standard package names, if the [internal Pants mapping](https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/blob/0e6719ac88d20b500bf0294d2f810ccd2bcf8d7e/src/python/pants/backend/python/dependency_inference/default_module_mapping.py#L6) could be extended in the global configuration file (that is, the root `pants.toml`).

For example, given the following section in the root `pants.toml` file:
```toml
[python-infer]
module_mapping.add = {
  "company-python-utils" = ["db_utils", "string_utils"],
  "company-python-creds" = ["company_creds"],
}
```
The config parser will do an equivalent to the following (made up pseudo code):
```python
import itertools

from pants.backend.python.dependency_inference.default_module_mapping import DEFAULT_MODULE_MAPPING


def get_module_mapping(
    parsed_pants_toml: dict,
    parsed_build_file: dict,
) -> dict:
    """
    Apply `python-infer.module_mapping.add` and `BUILD.__defaults__.python_requirements.module_mapping` if configured.
    """
    additions = itertools.chain(
        parsed_pants_toml.get("python-infer", {}).get("module_mapping", {}).get("add", {}).items(),
        parsed_build_file.get("__defaults__", {}).get("python_requirements", {}).get("module_mapping", {}).items(),
    )

    result = DEFAULT_MODULE_MAPPING.copy()
    for pypi_name, import_names in additions:
        result[pypi_name] = tuple(import_names)

    return result
```

For a repository that has an extensive use of non-standard package names in multiple packages, this will be a simple, efficient, and elegant solution.

Assuming the team is onboard with this idea (or a variation of it), I'd like to offer to put up a PR with an implementation.
Note that in that case, that would be my first PR for Pants, so I'd appreciate a few pointers on how to adjust the example above (or the alternative) to the actual project.

        parsed_pants_toml.get("python-infer", {}).get("module_mapping", {}).get("add", {}).items(),
        parsed_build_file.get("__defaults__", {}).get("python_requirements", {}).get("module_mapping", {}).items(),
    )

    result = DEFAULT_MODULE_MAPPING.copy()
    for pypi_name, import_names in additions:
        result[pypi_name] = tuple(import_names)

    return result
```

For a repository that has an extensive use of non-standard package names in multiple packages, this will be a simple, efficient, and elegant solution.

Assuming the team is onboard with this idea (or a variation of it), I'd like to offer to put up a PR with an implementation.
Note that in that case, that would be my first PR for Pants, so I'd appreciate a few pointers on how to adjust the example above (or the alternative) to the actual project.

comment.body:
My bad, I will clarify
There are 2 use-cases I see for this feature.

The first use-case is an organization-internal package which is in another repo.
For example, if it is owned by another division in the company and thus has its own (maybe mono) repo.

The second use-case is that there is a package on PyPi that is not yet in the [internal Pants mapping](https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/blob/0e6719ac88d20b500bf0294d2f810ccd2bcf8d7e/src/python/pants/backend/python/dependency_inference/default_module_mapping.py#L6), so as a temp fix it can be added for that repo.

issue.title: Support `BUILD`.`module_mapping` for Python package inference in `pants.toml`
issue.body:
It would be easier and more intuitive to support organization-internal (first-party) non-standard package names, if the [internal Pants mapping](https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/blob/0e6719ac88d20b500bf0294d2f810ccd2bcf8d7e/src/python/pants/backend/python/dependency_inference/default_module_mapping.py#L6) could be extended in the global configuration file (that is, the root `pants.toml`).

For example, given the following section in the root `pants.toml` file:
```toml
[python-infer]
module_mapping.add = {
  "company-python-utils" = ["db_utils", "string_utils"],
  "company-python-creds" = ["company_creds"],
}
```
The config parser will do an equivalent to the following (made up pseudo code):
```python
import itertools

from pants.backend.python.dependency_inference.default_module_mapping import DEFAULT_MODULE_MAPPING


def get_module_mapping(
    parsed_pants_toml: dict,
    parsed_build_file: dict,
) -> dict:
    """
    Apply `python-infer.module_mapping.add` and `BUILD.__defaults__.python_requirements.module_mapping` if configured.
    """
    additions = itertools.chain(
        parsed_pants_toml.get("python-infer", {}).get("module_mapping", {}).get("add", {}).items(),
        parsed_build_file.get("__defaults__", {}).get("python_requirements", {}).get("module_mapping", {}).items(),
    )

    result = DEFAULT_MODULE_MAPPING.copy()
    for pypi_name, import_names in additions:
        result[pypi_name] = tuple(import_names)

    return result
```

For a repository that has an extensive use of non-standard package names in multiple packages, this will be a simple, efficient, and elegant solution.

Assuming the team is onboard with this idea (or a variation of it), I'd like to offer to put up a PR with an implementation.
Note that in that case, that would be my first PR for Pants, so I'd appreciate a few pointers on how to adjust the example above (or the alternative) to the actual project.
